front: What is declination?
back: The difference between Magnetic North and True North (in degrees)

front: What is the declination for El Dorado County?
back: 13 degrees

front: How do you convert from Magnetic to True North?
back: Add 13 degrees (Compass to Map Add - turn bezel to the right)

front: How do you convert from True to Magnetic North?
back: Subtract 13 degrees (Map to Compass Subtract - turn bezel to the left)

front: What is Magnetic North?
back: Direction a magnetized compass needle points as it aligns to Earth's magnetic field

front: What is True North?
back: Direction of shortest distance between anyplace on the earth's surface and the North Pole

front: What is a datum in navigation?
back: A 3D model of the earth based on thousands of benchmark measurements

front: Which datum does EDSAR use?
back: WGS-84 (World Geodetic Survey of 1984)

front: What are the three datum options?
What does UTM stand for and what is it?
back: Universal Transverse Mercator - a 2D coordinate grid system dividing the earth into meters, with major grid at 1km

front: How many UTM zones are there for Easting?
back: 60 zones (West to East)

front: What UTM zones is California in?
back: Zones 10S, 10T, and 11S

front: How do you read UTM coordinates?
back: Zone, Easting, Northing (read Right then Up)

front: What letter is used for the Equator in UTM Northing?
back: O (not shown on map)

front: What are the steps to orient a map using True North?
back: Set bezel to 347° (360° - 13°), align compass edge to map grid line, rotate map until red is in the shed

front: What is the first step in the methodical method to orient a map?
back: Orient the map to the terrain (check that the bottom map symbol is facing up)

front: What are the 5 major terrain features?
back: Hills, Valleys, Ridgelines, Saddles, and Depressions

front: How do you identify a Hill on a topographic map?
back: Concentric circles with elevation increasing; ground goes down in all directions

front: How do you identify a Valley on a topographic map?
back: V or U shaped lines pointing uphill; ground goes up in 3 directions, down in one

front: How do you identify a Ridgeline on a topographic map?
back: V or U shaped lines pointing downhill; ground goes down in 3 directions, up in 1

front: How do you identify a Saddle on a topographic map?
back: Connects two mountains, contour lines can bend inward, can be hourglass shaped

front: How do you identify a Depression on a topographic map?
back: Circle with tick marks on the inside; ground goes up in all directions

front: What is a Spur in terrain navigation?
back: A minor feature that juts off from a ridgeline (like fingers); contour lines go down

front: What is a Draw in terrain navigation?
back: A minor feature between spurs, formed by runoff; creeks flow down, contour lines go up

front: What is a Cliff on a topographic map?
back: Contour lines that are really close together, indicating very steep terrain

front: What color represents water on USGS topo maps?
back: Blue

front: What color represents vegetation on USGS topo maps?
back: Green

front: What color represents contour lines on USGS topo maps?
back: Brown

front: What color represents roads on USGS topo maps?
back: Red (can also be in black, can be dotted)

front: What color represents man-made objects on USGS topo maps?
back: Black

front: How do you calibrate a compass on a Garmin 64s?
back: [PAGE] > scroll to Compass > [MENU] > Calibrate Compass > Start > follow screen instructions

front: What Lat/Long format does EDSAR use?
back: DDD° MM.MMM' (degrees, minutes, decimal minutes)

front: How do you read Lat/Long coordinates?
back: Read South to North (latitude), then East to West (longitude)

front: Where is the reference point for Latitude and Longitude?
back: Equator and 0 degrees in Greenwich, England

front: How many minutes are in a degree of Lat/Long?
back: 60 minutes per degree

front: How many seconds are in a minute of Lat/Long?
back: 60 seconds per minute

front: What is the ASSA rule for navigating around obstacles?
back: If you need to turn right: Add 90°, Subtract 90°, Subtract 90°, Add 90° (original bearing)

front: What is the SAAS rule for navigating around obstacles?
back: If you need to turn left: Subtract 90°, Add 90°, Add 90°, Subtract 90° (original bearing)

front: What should you do when changing bearings while navigating?
back: Put red in the shed each time you change the bearing, and count your paces when moving perpendicular

front: How large is each UTM map square?
back: 1 kilometer

front: How do you plot UTM coordinates on a map?
back: Read right for Easting, then up for Northing; use reader to pinpoint last 3 digits

front: What should you do if the grid reader scale doesn't fit the map square?
back: Diagonally angle reader on map square until 0 and 10 touches borders, make tick marks based on grid lines

front: How do you plot Lat/Long coordinates on a map?
back: Use black tick marks on map, read South to North (Lat), then East to West (Long), use ruler to divide and isolate exact coordinates

front: What should you consider when planning a route on a map?
back: Map symbols, navigable paths (roads, trails), size, shape, slope, orientation, elevation change, and terrain

front: How do you create a proximity alarm on a Garmin 64s?
back: [Menu 2x] > Proximity Alarms > Create Alarm > Waypoints > select waypoint > enter radius

front: How do you mark a waypoint on a Garmin 64s?
back: [MARK] > arrow into fields to enter the name and location coords > Done

front: How do you get a magnetic bearing to an object?
back: Point the compass at the object, rotate the bezel until red is in the shed

front: How do you identify an object on a given bearing?
back: Rotate the bezel until the bearing is at the compass index, turn your body until red is in the shed

front: How do you convert from Compass to Map bearing in EDC?
back: Add 13 degrees

front: How do you convert from Map to Compass bearing in EDC?
back: Subtract 13 degrees

front: What are the steps to plot a True bearing on a map?
back: 1) Draw line between 2 points 2) Place compass edge on line pointing direction of travel 3) Rotate bezel to align orienting lines with map grid 4) Read bearing at index

front: Before walking with a bearing from a map, what must you do?
back: Subtract 13 degrees (convert to Magnetic North), put red in the shed, move in direction of travel arrow

front: What is the key principle to remember during triangulation?
back: Needle doesn't matter and you don't know your direction of travel

front: What are the main steps for triangulation?
back: 1) Orient map to terrain 2) Get bearings by pointing compass, red in shed 3) Convert to True North (+13°) 4) For each landmark: set bezel, place corner on landmark, pivot to match grid lines, draw line

front: When should you use back azimuth during triangulation?
back: When you're falling off the map when you pivot the compass

front: What is the allowed error variance for UTM coordinates on the test?
back: 10 meters

front: What is the proper format for communicating GPS coordinates over radio?
back: Ready to relay coordinates, please advise when ready to copy. 10S...Easting [BREAK]...Northing...WSG-84 (pause) how copy?

front: How do you save your current location as a waypoint on Garmin 64s?
back: Press [MARK] button

front: How do you create a route segment on a Garmin 64s?
back: Create waypoints first, then [Menu 2x] > Route Planner > Create Route > Select First Point > select waypoints including starting waypoint at the end

front: What is the EDSAR track naming nomenclature?
back: GPS: (Search ID)(Team#)(Team Type Prefix)(Initials) e.g., FT101FDW

front: What are the Team Type Prefixes in EDSAR?
back: F(oot), M(ounted), S(wiftwater), I(ncident Support), O(HV), U(AS), K(9), T(echnical Rope)

front: How do you clear an active track on Garmin 64s?
back: [Menu 2x] > Track Manager > Current Track > Clear Current Track

front: How do you save a track on Garmin 64s?
back: [Menu 2x] > Track Manager > Current Track > Save Track > enter SAR nomenclature

front: What is 'red in the shed'?
back: A phrase meaning to align the red compass needle with the red orienting arrow inside the compass bezel

front: What does the mnemonic 'Hidden Valley Ranch Salad Dressing' help you remember?
back: The major terrain features: Hills, Valleys, Ridgelines, Saddles, Depressions

front: When plotting a bearing, where should the compass N/orienting arrow point?
back: Towards the top of the map (True North)

front: What is the direction of travel arrow on a compass?
back: The arrow on the baseplate that shows which direction you should walk

front: What are orienting lines on a compass?
back: The parallel lines inside the compass bezel that should align with map grid lines
